channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: The World Responds to India's Distress Call
item.description: Countries, companies and powerful members of the diaspora have all pledged to pitch in, but it likely won’t be enough to stop the unfolding catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man receiving oxygen outside a Sikh house of worship in Delhi on Sunday.

item.title: A Graying China May Have to Put Off Retirement. Workers Aren’t Happy.
item.description: Most Chinese workers retire by 60. But with the population aging and pension funds running low, the government says that must change.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press
item.media:description: An auto assembly line in Wuhan, China. China has some of the lowest retirement ages in the world.

item.title: Indonesian General Is Killed in Rebel Ambush, Sparking Fears of Retaliation
item.description: President Joko Widodo announced the death of the high ranking intelligence chief and called for the arrest of rebel gunmen. Activists said they feared reprisals against Indigenous Papuans.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Indonesian Presidential Palace, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Joko Widodo of Indonesia on Monday expressed his condolences and vowed revenge after Papuan separatists killed the top intelligence official in the province.

item.title: Chair Incident Was Sign of Enduring Sexism, E.U. Leader Says
item.description: “Would this have happened if I had worn a suit and a tie?” asked Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, after she was left standing during a summit in Turkey this month.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Turkish Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still from a video showing the moment when Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, was left standing during a visit to Turkey this month for a meeting with president Recep Tayyip Erdogan, right.

item.title: Prince Philip's Death Adds Urgency to Royal Family's Transition
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II is increasingly withdrawing to Windsor Castle, royal watchers say, while Prince Charles is stepping forward.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Phil Harris
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain with Prince Charles; Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall; Prince William; and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, in Westminster Abbey in London last year.

item.title: E.U. Sues AstraZeneca Over Missing Vaccine Doses
item.description: The legal action escalates a longstanding dispute over shortfalls in deliveries, even as Brussels is seeking to shift to other suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Martin Divisek/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A delivery driver with two boxes of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine in Prague in February. The European Union says the company is on track to deliver only 100 million of a promised 300 million doses by June.

item.title: Greek Neo-Nazi Lawmaker Stripped of Immunity by European Parliament
item.description: Ioannis Lagos, sentenced to 13 years in prison by a Greek court for his part in running the fascist Golden Dawn party, had been immune from extradition as an elected member of the European Union’s legislature.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Thanassis Stavrakis/Associated Press
item.media:description: The European Parliament member Ioannis Lagos waiting for his sentencing outside a court in Athens last year.

item.title: Russia Suspends Public Activity by Navalny’s Political Groups
item.description: Prosecutors have temporarily muzzled the opposition leader’s political groups, banning them from protests and posting on social media. But a court ruling may well make that permanent.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Yuri Kochetkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police officers near the headquarters of Aleksei A. Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation in Moscow in January.

item.title: The E.U. May Reopen to Vaccinated American Tourists. Here's What to Know.
item.description: The head of the European Commission said the bloc was working to allow vaccinated visitors from the U.S. this summer. Questions remain about how and when that might happen.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Gallerie D’Italia in Milan reopened on Monday as Italy loosened its lockdown restrictions in some areas.

item.title: A Population Bust
item.description: We look at the upsides and downsides of slow population growth in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child-care facility in Queens.

item.title: Indonesia Submarine Crew Sang a Farewell Song, Weeks Before Sinking
item.description: A video of the sailors singing went viral on social media, prompting many to infer a hidden meaning in the pop song’s lyrics.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Indonesian Military, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image from a video released by the Indonesian Navy, in which the crew of the submarine Nanggala sang the pop song “Till We Meet Again.”

item.title: Thailand's Prime Minister Forgoes a Mask and Pays a Fine
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Athit Perawongmetha/Reuters
item.media:description: Thailand’s prime minister Prayuth Chan-ocha arriving at the Government House in Bangkok last month.

item.title: Biden Administration Hopes to Learn Fate of U.S. Hostage in Syria
item.description: While hopes for the return of Austin Tice have faded, the top American hostage negotiator says he believes the former journalist is still alive.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Bilal Hussein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Marc and Debra Tice, the parents of Austin Tice, have pressed the government to help find out what happened to their son.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Travel to the E.U. for vaccinated Americans.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Place des Vosges in central Paris earlier this month.

item.title: Brazil Rejects Using Russia's Sputnik V Covid Vaccine
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.category: Gamaleya Research Institute of Epidemiology and Microbiology
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Sputnik V vaccine production line in Saint Petersburg, Russia in February.

item.title: West Virginia To Pay $100 to Some Who Get Covid Vaccine
item.description: The governor said he hoped the payments, which will come from federal stimulus money, would motivate younger residents to get inoculated.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: Stephen Zenner/Getty Images
item.media:description: Health care workers prepared doses of a Covid-19 vaccine in Buffalo, W.Va., last month. Gov. Jim Justice announced a plan to give savings bonds to young people who get vaccinated.

item.title: Biden to Send Coronavirus Vaccine Abroad
item.description: President Biden will send up to 60 million doses of AstraZeneca’s vaccine to countries pleading for help, but some see a medicine dropper for “a four-alarm fire.”
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: People receiving oxygen treatments for Covid-19 on Sunday in Delhi. On Monday, India broke the world record for daily coronavirus infections for a fifth consecutive day, reporting nearly 353,000 new cases.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Aid for India’s coronavirus crisis.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A line at the Louvre in Paris last summer. The European Union is allowing fully vaccinated Americans entry into the bloc this summer.

item.title: Lockdowns Cut South Asia Smog. They Could Fill Reservoirs, Too.
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions reduced pollution that makes snow melt faster, which could help water supplies for 300 million last longer this year.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Aamir Qureshi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A suspension bridge over the Indus River in Skardu, in Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan, in January.

item.title: Supreme Court to Rule on Whether C.I.A. Black Sites Are State Secrets
item.description: A Guantánamo detainee is seeking information from two former government contractors in connection with a Polish criminal inquiry into a facility there.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Artur Reszko/AFP
item.media:description: An airport in Szymany, Poland, where C.I.A. planes were said to have landed in 2002 and 2003. An inquiry into whether a C.I.A. detainee was tortured at so-called black sites, including one in Poland, was prompted by a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights.

item.title: Germany plans to make all adults eligible for vaccination starting in June.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vaccinating medical workers at the Grosshadern Hospital in Munich last month.

item.title: France Seeks Change in Law After Outrage Over Verdict in Anti-Semitic Killing
item.description: The proposed bill, which would prevent intoxication being used as a basis for a plea of insanity, was prompted by a verdict allowing the killer of a Jewish woman to avoid trial.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Geoffroy Van Der Hasselt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A large crowd gathered in Paris on Sunday to demand justice for Sarah Halimi, a Jewish woman killed in 2017 by a man who will not face criminal charges.

item.title: A Look at Covid-19 Vaccine ‘Passports,’ Passes and Apps Around the Globe
item.description: A variety of digital and old-fashioned approaches are being used to confirm vaccination for entry to public places. But the world is still far from a universal standard of proof for crossing borders.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy

item.title: Surging virus variants push the Philippines over a million total cases.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Eloisa Lopez/Reuters
item.media:description: Coronavirus patients at a hospital in Quezon City were treated on wheelchairs because of a shortage of beds.

item.title: Fans come out in prepandemic numbers for an Australian rules football match.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Quinn Rooney/Getty Images
item.media:description: The crowd stood for the Last Post during the round six A.F.L. match between the Collingwood Magpies and the Essendon Bombers at Melbourne Cricket Ground on Sunday.

item.title: In France, an Ever-Extending Labyrinth of Covid Lockdowns
item.description: Walk the dog? Only one kilometer. Want a raclette maker? Sure. A lamp? Nope. During the pandemic, France’s bureaucracy has hit overdrive, and the French are increasingly fed up.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nonessential items surrounded by red-and-white tape, off limits at a store in Paris this month.

item.title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe Is Sentenced to Another Year in Custody in Iran
item.description: Ms. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British-Iranian dual citizen who was released from detention last month, was handed the sentence and a one-year travel ban on new charges of “propaganda activities.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Boyers/Reuters
item.media:description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe’s husband, Richard Ratcliffe, and their daughter holding a poster of her outside the Iranian Embassy in London last month.

item.title: E.U. Sues AstraZeneca Over Missed Vaccine Deliveries
item.description: The legal action escalates a longstanding dispute over shortfalls in deliveries, even as Brussels is seeking to shift to other suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering the AstraZeneca vaccine at the Milan military hospital last month.

item.title: With U.K. Cases Low, Scotland and Wales Reopen Restaurants and Stores
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andy Buchanan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A pub in Glasgow, Scotland on Monday.

item.title: South Korea Celebrates Oscar Win for Youn Yuh-jung of 'Minari'
item.description: Ms. Youn is the first Asian woman to win the best supporting actress Oscar since 1957. But it’s her life story — as well as her characters — that made her award resonate among Koreans.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Todd Wawrychuk/Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Yuh-Jung Youn, the first Korean woman in Oscar history to win best supporting actress.

item.title: Hong Kong and Singapore set a new date for the start of a long-delayed travel bubble.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hikers at Lion Rock in Hong Kong in January.

item.title: India’s New Covid Mystery
item.description: Many people in India thought the country had escaped the worst of Covid-19. What happened?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient in Delhi yesterday.

item.title: China Censors Chloé Zhao’s Oscar Win
item.description: On social media, the director’s fans blurred out her name and turned images on their sides to evade the censors. “People should be celebrating,” one writer said.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Todd Wawrychuk/Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chloé Zhao accepting the Oscar for directing for “Nomadland.”

item.title: India continues to shatter case records as it awaits international aid.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for hospital beds, Covid-19 patients received oxygen provided by a local Sikh house of worship on a sidewalk in New Delhi on Sunday.

item.title: Italy’s Problem With School Dropouts Goes From Bad to Worse in Pandemic
item.description: Even before the coronavirus hit, Italy had among the worst dropout rates in Europe. But closed schools and online classes have pushed students out in ever higher numbers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teenagers in Scampia, a district on the outskirts of Naples, Italy.

item.title: Sweden, Dressed in Summer
item.description: We’ve shown you Sweden in snow. Now see it in bloom.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Westberg
item.media:credit: Marcus Westberg
item.media:description: A fox in a field near the photographer’s home.

item.title: Terrorist Group Steps Into Venezuela as Lawlessness Grows
item.description: With Venezuela in shambles, criminals and insurgents run large stretches of the nation’s territory. We traveled through one of the regions under their control.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: José Manuel Gonzalez sitting near the graves of his two sons, killed during fighting between criminals over smuggling routes, in Guarero, Venezuela.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: India’s deadly coronavirus surge.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Iran’s Foreign Minister, in Leaked Tape, Says Revolutionary Guards Set Policies
item.description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, described a rivalry with a powerful and widely revered military leader, Qassim Suleimani.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran’s foreign minister.

item.title: U.S. to Send Virus-Ravaged India Materials for Vaccines
item.description: The Biden administration, under pressure to help with a surge raging out of control, will also supply therapeutics, test kits, ventilators and protective gear.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family hugging during the cremation of a loved one who died from the coronavirus in Delhi.

item.title: Gunfire Erupts in Mogadishu as Somalia’s Political Feud Turns Violent
item.description: Tensions had been rising since the president, a former American citizen, failed to hold scheduled elections, then extended his term in office by two years.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Hussein Mohamed
item.media:credit: Feisal Omar/Reuters
item.media:description: A supporter of the opposition in Mogadishu. Fighting on Sunday raised fears that Somalia’s political crisis could spill over into violence.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: India may be underreporting coronavirus numbers.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives mourning outside a hospital mortuary in Delhi after seeing bodies of Covid-19 victims on Friday.

item.title: Vaccinated American Tourists May Soon Travel to Europe
item.description: The head of the European Commission said the bloc would switch policy, under certain conditions, after more than a year of mostly banning nonessential travel.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before long American tourists may be able to visit Paris and the treasures of the Louvre, shown last summer.

item.title: U.S. to Send India Vaccine Materials and Other Aid
item.description: Previously, Biden administration officials had pushed back as pressure mounted for the U.S. to help combat the surge in India.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vaccinations at a government hospital in Mumbai this month.

item.title: Domestic Workers in the Gulf Open Up About Labor Conditions on Tiktok
item.description: Foreign employees in wealthy households — most of them women — have been using the video-sharing app to bring abuses to light.
item.dc:creator: Louise Donovan
item.media:credit: Brenda Dama, via TikTok
item.media:description: A still from a video posted on TikTok by Brenda Dama.

item.title: Killer of French Police Officer Was a Radicalized Islamist, Prosecutor Says
item.description: The attacker watched videos ‘glorifying martyrs and jihad’ immediately before the stabbing, the official said.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Ian Langsdon/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The police in Rambouillet, southwest of Paris, guarded the police station on Friday where a female officer was stabbed to death.

item.title: US Military Begins Final Withdrawal from Afghanistan
item.description: The top American commander, Gen. Austin S. Miller, says he is often asked whether the Afghan forces are ready to fight the Taliban alone. His answer? ‘They must be ready.’
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. Army soldiers during training of the 215th Corps of the Afghan National Army at Camp Bastion in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in 2016.

item.title: U.S. Covid Vaccinations Fall, Even as Cases Remain High
item.description: The average number of vaccine shots given each day, which rose for months and peaked at 3.38 million, has now fallen to 2.86 million, the lowest level since March 31.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz, Andrea Kannapell and Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: A pop-up Covid-19 vaccination center in Newark on Friday. The United States is vaccinating fewer people on a daily basis than earlier this month, though coronavirus cases remain stubbornly high.

item.title: Alber Elbaz, Beloved Fashion Designer, Is Dead at 59
item.description: A favorite of celebrities like Meryl Streep and Natalie Portman, he rejuvenated Lanvin and had recently started his own brand. He died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Thomas Coex/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Elbaz after showing his collection for Guy Laroche’s Spring/Summer ready-to-wear show in Paris in 1999.

item.title: Baghdad Hospital Fire Kills at Least 82, Many of Them Coronavirus Patients
item.description: A blaze set off by an exploding oxygen cylinder swept through a hospital that lacked smoke detectors or sprinklers. More are expected to die from severe burns.
item.dc:creator: Falih Hassan and Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Murtaja Lateef/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The aftermath of a fire at a hospital in Baghdad on Sunday.

item.title: Phuket Was Poised for Tourism Comeback. A Covid Surge Dashed Those Hopes.
item.description: Phuket, one of Thailand’s top tourist havens, had an ambitious plan to reopen to the world this summer. But with a spike in cases, the island’s desperate situation is unlikely to end anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bars and nightclubs at Patong Beach have been ordered closed because of a recent Covid-19 outbreak on Phuket Island in Thailand, this month.

item.title: Spanish police arrested a man for spreading the coronavirus to 22 people.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.media:credit: Cati Cladera/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Police officers patrolled an empty beach in Mallorca, Spain, earlier this month.

item.title: New Zealand Hosts 50,000 Fans in Largest Concert Since the Pandemic Began
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: David Rowland/Associated Press
item.media:description: Fans filled the stadium as the band Six60 performed at Eden Park in Auckland, New Zealand, on Saturday.

item.title: English Soccer Will Boycott Social Media to Protest Online Abuse
item.description: The boycott, set to begin on Friday, is the most direct effort yet by a sport to pressure social media companies like Twitter, Instagram and Facebook to take action against abuse.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Andrew Das

item.title: Africa's Vaccine Drive Is Threatened by India's Supply Halt
item.description: India’s dire Covid crisis is having global ripple effects, especially in Africa, which has 17 percent of the world’s people but is far behind in vaccinations.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People waited to register for a Covid-19 vaccine in Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday.

item.title: 4 Astronauts Float Into the International Space Station and Open Arms
item.description: The crew arrived on Saturday on the Dragon Endeavour, a spacecraft built by SpaceX, Elon Musk’s space exploration company.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Nasa TV
item.media:description: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station on Saturday welcomed the four members of Crew-2 Dragon Endeavour, the private spacecraft launched by SpaceX.
